chapter.htmlHeader: What causes hearing loss?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The most common causes of hearing loss are ageing and exposure to excessive noise. Other causes include exposure to ototoxic substances and a wide variety of genetic, systemic and infective conditions.

  • Causes of conductive hearing loss include:
    • Impacted earwax (cerumen).
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Earwax.
    • Foreign bodies for example cotton bud tips.
    • Tympanic membrane perforation.
      • May be caused by direct trauma (for example from a head injury or cotton bud), barotrauma (for example from scuba diving), or infection (for example otitis media).
    • Infection for example otitis externa and otitis media.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Otitis externa and Otitis media - acute.
    • Cholesteatoma.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Cholesteatoma.
    • Middle ear effusion.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Otitis media with effusion.
    • Otosclerosis.
      • Abnormal bone growth affecting the small bones of the ear (mainly the stapes) — other family members may also be affected.
    • Neoplasm such as squamous cell carcinoma of the external ear and vascular glomus tumour behind the eardrum.
    • Exostoses — hard bony growths in the ear canal (associated with swimming in cold water).
  • Causes of sensorineural hearing loss include:
    • Age-related hearing loss (presbycusis) — the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss.
      • Aetiology is multifactorial and includes degenerative changes associated with ageing, vascular changes, and genetic and environmental factors.
    • Noise exposure — this may be temporary or permanent.
    • Sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSHL)
      • SSHL is defined as sudden onset (within 72 hours) hearing loss of 30 dB HL (decibel hearing level) or more which involves 3 consecutive frequencies and cannot be explained by outer or middle ear conditions.
      • In 90% of cases no underlying cause is identified and SSNHL is considered to be idiopathic.
      • Hearing loss can range from mild to profound and may be temporary or permanent.
    • Meniere’s disease.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Meniere's disease.
    • Exposure to ototoxic substances such as:
      • Drugs including aminoglycoside antibiotics (for example gentamicin), loop diuretics (for example bumetanide and furosemide), non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, aspirin, anti-malarials (for example quinine and chloroquine), and cytotoxic drugs (for example cisplatin and bleomycin).
      • Environmental and other toxins such as pesticides, cigarette smoke and heavy metals (for example mercury and lead).
    • Labyrinthitis.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Vertigo.
    • Vestibular schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma).
      • A benign tumour which can cause hearing loss by compressing the cochlear nerve — may in some cases grow into the posterior cranial fossa and cause brain stem compression.
    • Neurological conditions such as multiple sclerosis or stroke.
    • Malignancy including nasopharyngeal cancer and intracranial tumours.
    • Trauma to the head or ear.
    • Systemic infections — congenital (such as cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, syphilis) or acquired (such as meningitis, HIV, measles, Lyme disease, or herpes zoster [Ramsay-Hunt syndrome]).
    • Autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, sarcoidosis, Wegners granuloma (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) and autoimmune inner ear disease.
    • Hereditary conditions such as Alports syndrome (a genetic condition associated with progressive renal impairment and hearing loss).
